items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Further heavy rainfall is forecast throughout today, 28/12/2022, will cause lake levels to remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Flooding is possible on the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Further rainfall is forecast throughout this week and the weekend. Lake and river levels are high and may rise further, the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and will issue the flood warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Due to industrial action, we will be temporarily automating our messages, this message cannot be updated during this time.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels have risen on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck. Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Flooding is possible from 05:00 PM on 28/12/2022. Further showery rainfall is forecast overnight, we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Due to industrial action, we will be temporarily automating our messages, this message cannot be updated during this time.

items.message: This flood alert remains in force as weather conditions along the coast are forecast to cause overtopping waves and spray on Wednesday 28/12/2022, between 9:00 PM and midnight. Areas most at risk include areas of Bridlington around the lifeboat station and South Pier. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This alert may also need to be in force for further high tides later this week. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 12:00 noon is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with westerly force 8 winds and large waves.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 12:00 noon on 28/12/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Christchurch Harbour.
We will remove this message by 03:00 PM on 28/12/2022.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Flooding is possible in this area.  
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. 
The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels.
This message will not be updated as often as usual, as the Flood Warning System will be automated from 17:00 on Wednesday 28/12/2022 until 09:00 on Friday 06/01/2023 due to ongoing industrial action. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.Â  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Â Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels have risen at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of rainfall overnight and today, 28/12/22.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this afternoon.  Flooding will affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Levels will continue to rise and then remain high before starting to fall overnight. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

items.message: River levels are rising at the Bradford on Avon river gauge due to recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. From 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, continue to take care near coastal paths and promenades.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 14:30 on 28/12/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.58 m. The total forecast tide is 4.70 metres Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, large waves will cause spray overtopping and overwashing of defences across the exposed coast at Freshwater Bay, Sandown, Shanklin, Gurnard and Ryde. This will flood sea front esplanades, car parks and roads. As Cowes is largely sheltered from the waves, impacts will be more minimal. We do not expect property flooding. At 03:45 on 29/12/2022, as wave heights remain elevated, some minor impact spray overtopping affecting the southern coastal frontage may continue. After this time, no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. At high tide, avoid parking, walking or driving at exposed sea front locations. We will remove this message by 18:00 on 28/12/2022.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Wednesday, 28/12/22 and over the coming days. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. The rainfall today has passed through and further rain is forecast tonight, followed by showers tomorrow. Additional rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low-lying roads and footpaths near local watercourses. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

River levels remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall.
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is continuing. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre maybe flooded.  
Further rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 28/12/22, and over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain elevated.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for some rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday 28th December. 

There has been heavy rainfall overnight accompanied by strong winds. Rivers have reacted and there remains a risk of flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Watercourses in the area will remain high throughout Wednesday, although no flooding to properties is expected.  

Rain is forecast to clear this afternoon to be followed by scattered showers. The next frontal system is likely to move in on Friday bringing further persistent rainfall. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated later this afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 15:15 on 28/12/22 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.42m. The total forecast tide is 5.95 metres Chart Datum (2.90 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane from the right of the East car park, towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Large waves, a similarly high tide and minor flood impacts are forecast early Thursday morning too. Waves will remain large all week but flood risk should reduce as tides fall by Friday. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 28/12/22.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday evening and into Thursday.
Heavy rainfall has been falling in the Dartmoor area. This has caused water levels in the River Dart and its tributaries to rise. 

Flooding to low lying land and roads is expected and we also expect the rivers to remain high and will remain sensitive to further rainfall.  We may issue Flood Warnings as necessary.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are constantly monitoring river levels and will have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on the afternoon of Thursday 29 December 2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: Levels have risen in the Washford River, as a result of the rainfall overnight and this morning. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022, and over the coming days in response to any further rain. Flooding of low-lying land is possible from the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. The current rain is forecast to pass through by early afternoon today, followed by some more rain tonight and showers tomorrow. Further rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Please refer to local authority websites for local road conditions. Please note, from 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. 
Further rainfall is forecast today, Wednesday 28/12/22, and over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain elevated.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels are rising at the Great Somerford river gauge due to recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is expected from today, Wednesday 28/12/2022. River levels are expected to rise again in response to this rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Refer to local authority website for local road closures. From 17:00 on 28/12/2022 the flood warning service is scheduled to be automated. We will be unable to update the text in this message during automation.

The rainfall today, Wednesday 28/12/2022, has passed through and further rain is forecast tonight, followed by showers tomorrow. Additional rain is forecast for Friday, 30/12/2022, and the weekend. Further rain is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions in your area. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.

items.message: The flood alert remains in force for the Upper River Ouse. Flooding is possible for riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Be prepared. River levels are rising on the river Ouse during Wednesday, 28/12/2022 due to recent persistent rainfall. Further bands of rain are forecast over the coming days, which may cause river levels to remain high. We have teams on standby to operate the Foss Barrier if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Areas most likely to be affected are Hendon Promenade and Seaburn Lower Promenade.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of recent rainfall. This alert has been issued due to elevated river levels around Sandford. This message will not be updated, but river levels may rise further and come out of banks. Please take care when walking along the Thames Path and check River Levels online for current levels at Kings Lock, Godstow Lock, Osney Lock, Iffly Lock, Minns Estate and Cold Harbour.
 
We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent, prolonged rainfall. Levels will continue to rise over the next few days and flooding of fields and some minor roads is expected.  Further rainfall is expected over the coming weekend. Due to a BT fault data from the Woodyates borehole is currently unavailable online, however today's reading is 93.95 metres above sea level.
Looking further ahead next week will be relatively dry, but with the possibility of stormy conditions appearing at the end of the week.

This flood warning remains in force as weather conditions along the coast are forecast to cause overtopping waves and spray on Thursday 29/12/2022, between 10.00 AM and 11:30 AM. Properties most at risk are in Scarborough at Sandside around the Old Harbour. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. We continue to monitor the forecast closely. Visit the GOV.UK website to see the current flood warnings, view river and sea levels or check the 5-day flood risk forecast.
